page.title: 09ARLINGTON ROW, BIBURY
page.content: Arlington Row was built as a wool barn but converted into weavers cottages in the 17th century. They are now owned by the National Trust and were restored in 1929. There were originally ten houses but now there are only eight. About half the residents were born locally, two of them in Arlington Row. They enjoy living in the Row but suffer a lack of privacy due to many visitors to a famous row of houses. One resident's family has lived in Arlington Row since 1890. She left after getting married but returned later. She does not like it as much now as in the old days. There are more holiday, weekend and retired people and not so many workers. She misses the community life and the closeness of the village people.
